reviewText:
Escaping from the void, trying to become more than you are and risking the world you seek in order to do so. This is the story of Nihilumbra, a puzzle based 2D platformer from Beautifun Games.

The game follows a vey narrative series of events travelling from the cold Icy hills through the forest, the desert, the volcano and finally to the city. Each location brings with it new challenges and a new skill to brave them. These skills come in the forms of colours, paints that can be spread around the environment at will. The first colour you obtain is blue, allowing the creation of ice. Then comes the green followed by the brown, creating bouncy and sticky surfaces respectively. From the volcano comes red, the ability to burn some things and  supercharge others. Finally there is yellow, the ability to create conductive lines to transfer power from energy sources to unpowered machines. It's the combination of all of these that will let you progress and aid in your escape from the void.

The gameplay is well established as you play, with a tutorial" for each new colour. The levels are relatively easy on the first play through but after finishing once there is a new "Void" version of the levels
date: being more difficult and involved. The controlling of the colours is intuitive and easy to do
recommended:
and if you make a mistake it's just as easy to undo your moves.

The visual style is fantastic with detailed painted backgrounds and foreground objects that have a parallax effect. When applying colours it is always easy to distinguish. The soundtrack is one that is extremely well fitting and only adds to the atmosphere. The voice over is a crucial part of the game and it wouldn't be the same without it. The tone of voice is one that makes the player feel safe while traveling and discovering.

Overall the game is solid and everything seems to work as intended

reviewText:
One of my all-time favorite games. Nihilumbra is a side-scrolling puzzle game, where you control the lone protoganist, Born, guiding him through five varied realms. Born is alone, too- aside from the enemies in the game, which are few and far between, every landscape you travel through seems abandoned, deserted. It adds an apocalyptic feel to an already stark and melancholy game.

Born starts out with very few tricks up his sleeve- he can jump and move inexorably to the right, and the enemies he encounters are deadly. As you progress, though, you pick up new skills that allow you to alter the landscape around you- colors you can paint on the world to allow you to slide, bounce, stick, and more.

There's really two parts to this game- the story mode, which is relatively straight-forward but still retains a challenge, and the mode you unlock after beating the story, which is devilishly hard. The controls seemed fluid to me, though they take some getting used to- one hand moves Born, while the mouse uses the various colors to guide him along. The game rarely rushes you, and when it does, it's considerate enough to provide enough checkpoints to prevent too much repetition.

This seems to be Beautifun's Freshman game for the PC, and I am definitely looking forward to where they'll go from here.

reviewText:
“Ew, a mobile game getting a PC port? No thanks!” You might say. But wait! Not all portable titles are games with simple yet addictive mechanics looking to take your money. Nihilumbra is a neat little puzzle platformer from Spanish developer Beautifun Games. You take control of Born, a creature created by The Void, who escapes to the real world. Relentlessly pursued by that which created him, Born treks across new and strange environments, discovering what it truly means to be alive.
He isn’t the only being from The Void that has crossed over however. Every now and then you will encounter a new enemy, each more dangerous than the last. These, combined with various environmental hazards provide much of the challenge outside of the platforming. The jumping itself isn’t complex, but as the game progresses you will discover new colours which can be painted on the walls, ceilings and ground of the levels. The game has five separate worlds, and there is a colour tied to each of them.
The Frozen Hills grants you blue, a colour to make surfaces icy, helping you run faster or push previously unmovable objects. The Living Forest gives you green, allowing you to make surfaces bouncy. The Ash Desert provides brown, which makes anything you paint it on sticky. The Volcano grants you red, which heats up surfaces to burn objects and enemies alike. Finally, The City unlocks yellow, which conducts electricity, allowing you to link electrical objects together. Thankfully the controls translate to keyboard and mouse perfectly. Painting is as simple as left clicking and dragging, and doing the same with right click acts as an eraser.
Although the game is 2D, the first two colours in particular have a very Portal 2-esque feel about them. You will be using momentum to jump and bounce your way to new platforms, and although it sometimes lacks precision, it isn’t all that frustrating. You will often use multiple colours in the same puzzle. For example you might use yellow to activate a powerful electromagnet, lifting your enemies into the air. Using brown on the floor in front of you allows you to walk along underneath them without being attracted yourself. There are a good amount of well thought out puzzles here. None of them take particularly long to figure out though. The game as a whole is not all that hard, and can be completed in a few hours at most – an unfortunate leftover from the fast paced mobile platform it was born on.
Nihilumbra employs a simple, yet effective art style. Each level has its own colourful theme, often attempting to give you a feel of the heat of the area. The icy areas are very blue, and the volcano is red, for obvious reasons, but this also related to the story. As Born uncovers new colours he begins to feel warmer inside, as if The Void inside him is being filled. The main character himself begins as an amorphous blob, but upon entering the real world he decides to change himself to try and blend in. The first thing he encounters is a scarecrow however, so you spend the rest of the game naively jumping around as a cute, raggedy old shadow creature. The character design of the Void enemies is good too, with weird plant creatures which launch projectiles at you, and a huge snail-like thing that erases any colours it slithers over.
At the end of each world, there is a fast paced platforming section where you are being chased by The Void. Ever encroaching from the left of the screen, you simply have to stay ahead of it and reach the end. These are some of the weakest sections of the game, as it shows off the lack of accuracy the platforming has at times. Switching between colours quickly is cumbersome, especially when attempted at speed. I would have liked the action to pause when bringing up the colour menu, as I often got caught out without the colour I needed. Thankfully the game is liberally checkpointed, even in the normal levels, so you never lose much progress. These checkpoints also seem to return all of your colour to you. It feels as if you are using some sort of resource when painting, but this was never explained, and I never ran out, so I can’t be sure.
All in all, Nihilumbra is a short, but fun, puzzle platformer. The puzzles you encounter aren’t all that difficult, but they do require some thought, particular in later stages. The platforming itself isn’t all that good, but the unique painting mechanics make up for it. Mobile games are becoming more complex, and simply better overall, and it is nice to see that some of the higher quality ones are making the switch over to PC.

reviewText:
There are dozens― hundreds, no doubt― of platformers that mimick this one in execution, you might be presuming. There are plenty of games with an art style similarly atmospheric, others that use colour or shadow as a gameplay mechanic. What about Limbo? Contrast? Why entertain this indie game when you can play those?

It certainly isn't the first platformer to capture my heart, but there is something undeniably special about Nihilumbra and it would be a crime to dismiss its own merits because you've met your quota for indie games this year.

Nihilumbra is a bleak but beautiful puzzle-platformer, stunning in its simplicity, that struck a chord with me in an emotionally cathartic, personal way. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

You are Born, an adorable creature from The Void, who spends the game fleeing because The Void wants you back where you belong. Home. The darkness. Born must run from the all-consuming Void, adapting to his new and vibrant surroundings in the real world, encountering enemies generated by The Void, with ever intensifying (occassionally timed) puzzle-solving. His desperation to escape inevitable capture at the clutches of this nothingness is not unlike struggling with depression and it resonated so powerfully with me I was all the more encouraged to keep on going. I was compelled to help Born live.

The story mode's puzzles are splendidly straightforward― yes, this could be a turn off for some― but it does allow for appreciation of other aspects of the game, such as:

• The story itself. Nihilumbra becomes less about the puzzles and more about the message behind the storytelling, which is profound in an uncomplicated sort of way.

• The somewhat unique gameplay mechanic of using colour to traverse platforms and solve puzzles. With a flick of your mouse you can coat the floor with red to burn away the shadow of a skeletal monster or propel yourself with icy blue across a previously unconquerable gap.

• The art. You can enjoy it in game or from the concept art section of the main menu, which unlocks as you finish each level. The enemy design is fittingly simplistic but interesting as well, with an Edward Gorey flair.

• It boasts a sublime soundtrack, which is understated but accompanies the game well.

• The narrator's voice is flat (deliberately, I believe, but I might be wrong) and ominous. He often points out the obvious and it reiterates how dire a situation Born is in. Although there is an option to turn the narrator off or lower the volume, I much prefer the game with him. He adds to the sense of despondency, but I realise this is a matter of debate.

• The aptly named Void Mode" which unlocks once you've completed the main story. This mode is tough as nails. I would argue that you haven't truly experienced what the game has to offer if you haven't subjected yourself to the teeth-grindingly frustrating (but ultimately doable) Void Mode. It is much more unforgiving and a decent challenge for those who thought the main game was a breeze.

Nihilumbra is well worth the asking price and it's a steal on sale. If nothing else
recommended: ethereal endeavour that should only require a couple of hours of your time to show you it is not a game to be ignored."

reviewText:
Nihilumbra raises questions about life and existence during its (3 hour or so) story. It's an unique game. One that I really enjoyed. It's a puzzle platformer game that's light on the puzzles; you have to use one or more of 5 colors to paint the landscapes and that way solve these puzzles. Paint the landscape green to jump, paint it brown to stick to the ground or use stealth, paint it yellow to generate electricity etc. At the beginning you'll use only one color, but after a few levels you'll be combining two or more colors in order to advance. The puzzles are never hard and even the most casual gamer will know how to solve these.

The voice acting is ok-ish. The narrator has a boring, uninteresting voice. I think no voice acting would've worked better in this case.

The graphics look okay for the most part. The environments are just perfectly fine, but the character you control as well as the enemies around you seem to lack animation frames. It all looks really basic and wooden in motion. A terrible shame. A few more frames would've definitely benefited this game. I didn't get immersed into the game and I think it's because of this. It's just too obvious. Anyway, enough about the animations.

Nihilumbra is a clever game that all gamers can and probably will enjoy. If not for the gameplay, then most likely for the story it's trying to tell. Recommended.

reviewText:
Nihilumbra is a poetic 2D platform game.
In my opinion, it's very similar to Limbo, but the game  also made me think about Another World and Heart Of Darkness for the design, the level-design and the gameplay.
The poetic side of the game is reinforced by the off-voice of the narrator in almost every screen of the story mode.
The story mode is not very difficult, and its main purpose is to tell a poetic story, the birth of the protagonist from the void, and his discovery of our world through different and various landscapes.
The gameplay is based on the mastering of colours, which have different properties, such as the possibility to slide, or to bounce, etc...

Once you've finished the story mode, you unlock the void mode.
Here, forget about the story, the poetism and the narration, it's all about thinking, skill and timing.
The void mode visits all levels of the story mode once again and modifies them into much harder puzzle levels.
It's somehow like the dark world in Super Meat Boy, but in a more easier way though.

I had a good time with this game, and I recommend it to every Limbo-like lovers.

Nihilumbra has just one big problem : its length.
It'll take you about 3 hours (maximum) to finish the story mode, and maybe the double to beat the void mode, depending on your skills.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful game with a stirring atmosphere and mood. A puzzle-platformer at it's core, it is immersive enough to make you forget that you're solving puzzles or dodging strange other-wordly creatures but feels more like a story that you're enjoying and experiencing.

I don't play many puzzle games and I still loved it so don't overlook this game because of the puzzle factor! I found the puzzles to be just right - they were sufficiently rewarding and never too frustrating to solve. The platforming is pretty straight forward and enhanced by some of the unique abilities the protagonist acquires (eg: being able to shoot a sticky-mud thing onto walls to cling onto or shooting bouncy grass or ice to reach sections otherwise inaccessible. There's some nice creativity at the core of this game.

Once you complete the main story (arguably not quite a 'story' in the traditional sense but still immensely enjoyable...) you unlock a harder version of the game - same areas with more complex puzzles. These, I safely avoided due to my aforetold indifference to hardcore puzzle games but that does add good replay value and may strike a chord with the puzzler in you.

In all - this is an excellent Indie title. You can even try the demo from the developer's website I believe if you're on the fence.

PS: IIRC I spent more than the 3.5 hours reported by Steam on this game (probably spent offline) but in any case this is a short game without any doubt, so bear that in mind.

reviewText:
Note: video review embedded below.

There’s a specific scene you revisit a few times throughout Nihilumbra. It begins with you falling, the world having been twisted into something surreal, yet oddly soothing. You don’t stay here long, but it was within these brief moments that I was able to collect the scattered thoughts swirling around in my head that I had previously been unable to make sense of.

These scenes represented to me what Nihilumbra was on a conceptual level. They’re beautiful, empty, and meaningless. The reason I was finding it so hard to take something away from Nihilumbra was because there was nothing there. It’s a gorgeous experience filled with expression, but its aesthetics are simply a mask with nothing underneath.

Nihilumbra tries relentlessly to carve out a philosophical core within its narrative, but it comes across as venting the poorly formed ideas of someone who has given up on the world rather than something profound. The writing feels forced and lacks any impact, obnoxiously attempting to make you feel something - anything - by simply stating those feelings as if that is somehow enough to bring them into existence. Ultimately the constant reminders that I was supposed to feel guilty or scared only caused me to become despondent and annoyed.

The detached way in which Nihilumbra handles morality makes it feel as if it doesn’t really care. It wants to come across as deep without having anything to actually say, filling its world with empty words that bounced off me as quickly as they reappeared.

Eventually I simply tuned the writing out and attempted to focus on the puzzle designs instead, yet doing this only brought out how similarly hollow and disinteresting those elements were too. Controlling various elemental powers which can be painted on the environment should provide endless interesting applications, but Nihilumbra never even scratches that surface. It provides you new tools at a steady pace but never a creative way to use them.

Puzzle designs repeat the same basic ideas the entire way through, often requiring no forethought as the answer is simply a slightly altered version of the tutorial. Nihilumbra isn’t just easy, it’s numbingly repetitive and unstimulating. The only time I felt challenged was in navigating the interface, which while not terrible tended to feel awkward and more suited to its touch-based origins than a mouse and keyboard. But then as if to mock me, completing the game unlocks “void mode”, which far from the simplistic main game radically raises the difficulty with cheap trial and error level designs. This doesn’t in turn make them any more engaging however, as the only thing being tested is your patience and how quickly you can move your fingers, rather than your puzzle solving skills.

Nihilumbra is such an exquisite game to look at, that it’s disheartening to see such lovely artwork was wasted on an experience that only manages to dull the senses. It functions, but provides no incentive to spend even a few hours to complete it. Playing it felt almost like it was actively pushing me out, unintentionally but forcefully, as if despite having outrun the void pursuing me it had already devoured the game itself.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4QDzcjqDf7E&ab_channel=MrNinjaSquirrel
You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
If there is one thing that could be held against Nihilumbra, it’s the game’s massive difficulty spike. There’s just no middle ground between “too easy” and “way too hard”.

If you consider yourself more of a casual puzzle solver, you’d better pick up Nihilumbra when it’s discounted.  It’s a well-made game and you will enjoy its first half.  If you’re ready for a challenge that keeps you engaged for a long time, the game is definitely worth its $9.99 price tag.

Altogether, this is an impressive first effort for a small studio. If you’re fond of the puzzle platformer genre, Nihilumbra is a must buy.

reviewText:
This game is a mixed bag from first glance. Honestly, the first half of the game is very dry and has copious amounts of needless narration. The narration is so rampant that you have to sit still each screen just to hear it, and honestly little is being said. To borrow from Shakespeare: the narrator speaks an infinite deal of nothing. It left a bad taste in my mouth as I felt the world could speak for itself in most cases. Less narration is more in this sense; the only reason why Bastion got away with gobs of narration is because there were interesting things to say, which were said in colorful ways. Do yourself a favor and drag the narration volume slider all the way to the left. The text alone, ironically, is more immersive since the narrator ends up getting cut off mid-sentence during normal play.

That said, the second half of the game is good. Don't get me wrong: the story is interesting, but the color mechanic is the real star of this game. The initial game is mostly a tutorial, while the void stages allow you to get creative with solving the problems ahead of you using the five colors you acquire during the main game. Many puzzles can be solved in multiple ways, some of them probably in ways not intended by the developer. However, I ran in to two major problems.

First off, there's some collision issues in the game, and often they can break puzzles entirely. In some cases, they are surmountable obstacles, such as the player's character getting snagged by the terrain. Those same snags, though, can send the player bouncing in different directions when using the green color. It's frustrating to be punished by the game for using the powers as intended.

Second, bullet collision is absolutely broken when vsync is on. It took me a while to figure this out, but my experience was tarnished by it. Several puzzles required bouncing bullets using the green color, and often those bullets would inexplicably implode before hitting a target. Some of the collision is off in the game, such as metal boxes, but turning off vsync at least allows the player to finish the game.

I definitely enjoyed the second half of the game way more than the first half, so take that with a grain of salt (and maybe wait for a sale), but I can still say this game is decent enough for someone looking for an interesting puzzle/platformer hybrid.

reviewText:
I. Love. This. Game.

I am one of those people that really loves the narration.  It reminds me of Portal mixed with this cool flash animation I once played.  The artwork is awesome, and I love the color scheme.  It was a lot of fun to play.

Now for a more in-depth review:

Main Story: This is a really nice indie puzzle game, and the feel is similar to Portal.  The concept of the colors is nice, but it does get repetitive the further you get into the game.  Accept that you'll die a few times on some of the levels because you won't be prepared for what's coming.  The puzzles are simple, though.  If anything, play through the entire main story.  It's short and worth trying.

Void Mode: Void mode is hard!  I'll give them that.  It's a nice challenge, but at times, it seems to be a little too difficult.  You have to have the timing just right to get through the levels.  As void mode goes on, you'll notice that some levels are super difficult and some are super easy.  It feels like the developers might have been running out of ideas as it goes on (or just gave up - the cave levels on void mode are super easy).  I got through the entire thing without help, so it's doable.  Just accept that you'll die many, many, many times to get through it.

Secret Language: If you get to this point, it is worth playing through the main storyline in the secret language.  It appears just to be the developer's rant mode.  Some of it is really stupid, but some of it is really funny...especially the end.  The one thing I didn't like is that they assumed that you are most likely a guy playing.  Ummmm...no.  I find that slightly offensive since I'm a girl and a gamer.

Achievements: They are super reasonable and at just the right difficulty.  I'll admit I did look up which level the Easter egg was hidden (though I didn't look up where in the level).  I would have eventually found it if I replayed the entire game again to look for it.  I saved that achievement for last (after already having played the game through three times), and I was being lazy.

Overall, I would highly recommend this game.  I don't think it's for everyone, but it is a fun way to pass the time.  Yes, it's worth the cost with or without a sale.  :)

reviewText: The mechanics are interesting and fairly well implemented, the graphics and music are forgettable yet passable, but the narration destroys this game. Firstly, the narrator is ever present, and rather than relaying a plot through environmental storytelling or immediate presentation, Nihilumbra consistently relies on the narrator's explicit descriptions. Second, the writing is extremely cheesy, constantly explicating and repeating how the protagonist, addressed in second person, is supposedly feeling as well as the considerations the game wants the player to make about the protagonist's relationship with and impact on the world. Mechanically, most puzzles are extremely easy, many solutions are given away immediately and explicitly by the narrator, and the same dynamics act as solutions to many, even subsequent, puzzles, making the levels feel like flavored repetitions of the same scenarios with no new challenge. New mechanics and dynamics are not explained through level design but rather explicated by the narrator, and the level design itself is not particularly clever although this is mostly insignificant due to the omnipresence of the guiding narration. In short, the awkward narrative explication of story, mechanics, dynamics, and solutions combined with repetitive puzzles and resulting low difficulty overwhelms the otherwise interesting mechanical potential and renders Nihilumbra a rather uninteresting game.

Just the fact that I've bothered to write a review with a recommendation should make obvious the fact that I got more than I expected. While the gameplay itself is cool (puzzle/platformer with a twist), the animations are great and the music isn't half bad either, what got me really interested is the story, or better yet - the storytelling.

The way the game is being presented somewhat reminds be of Bastion. You're introduced to a creature you know nothing about (the character you play), running from a mysterious enemy while discovering new worlds and developing along the way. Just like in Bastion, the narrator's script and voice acting make the game really easy to get into, and so far it seems like it's not getting old too quickly, either, as the game introduces a fun, original aspect of learning and using abilities.

Pros:

reviewText:
I picked this up during a Humble Bundle sale having never heard of it. I didn't know what to expect and really wasn't expecting much. To my surprise, Nihilumbra delivered and turned out to be one of the best and most underrated indie games I've ever played.

Story:You are Born. Born was created from The Void but has somehow separated from it and is now in the world. However, The Void will not allow this and is now chasing Born in an attempt to suck him back into the darkness. In order for Born to escape The Void, he must allow everything else in his path be destroyed.

Gameplay:Nihilumbra is a puzzle-platformer. As you progress through the game, Born will be granted new colors, which the player can use to paint the terrain in order to solve puzzles and aid him in his platforming. In total there are five different colors. Each have a different use and create a different effect. Throughout the game, Born will be accompanied by a narrator that will talk to him. It is uknown exactly who this narrator is whether he be Born, The Void or something else. The narrator really gives this game it's charm and gives insight to the world and what is going on. Sometimes he says some really philosophical things and it really adds to the atmosphere. Speaking of that, the atmosphere is amazing. The combination of colors, textures, music and narration sets a very solemn, yet relaxing mood. The main part of the game is very short. It only took me about 4 hours to complete. However, once you complete it, you'll unlock “Void Mode” which is essentially hard mode. Void Mode offers the same levels but with different and much harder puzzles.

Conclusion:Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone that's a fan of platformers or puzzle-platformers. It's really unique and highly underrated. Nihilumbra is a very insightful, relaxing and fun experience. That's what this game is. It's more than just a game. It's an experience to be had.

I think Nihilumbra kinda went under the radar for pretty much anyone or maybe I wasn't paying enough attention to the news. Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer with a very unique looking to it, you start the game being born in The Void and after you escape you end up on a strange world where The Void sends his creatures and it's coming to get you. The plot of this game along with a mindblowing soundtrack is what make them one of the best puzzle platformers of this year. According to the narrator, which identity remains a secret, The Void is one and you can't simply escape the void, he needs you in order to become one and that's why he's after you.

[MIGHT CONTAIN SPOILERS FROM NOW ON]

Your journey is divided in various environments ,you'll  travel to cold montains, a desert, a forest, volcanic fields and a city. Each of this places will great you an unique power which comes into place in the form of a colour and you can use them by clicking and dragging the mouse cursor on any surface, the montains grant you the blue colour which when used on any surface will make that surface slippery which will alow you to run or slide faster, the forest will grant you the green colour which if you jump on it it grants you a huge jump boost and sometimes is used for changing enemy projectiles course, in the desert you'll gain access to the brown colour which will grant you the power to slow things down or making you walk stealthly and even get enemies trapped in corners, the volcanic fields of course will grant you the red colour which when an enemy steps on it (including yourself) it will start burning and this is the first time you can actually kill an enemy by yourself and last but by no means least, the city which takes a huge role on the story grants you the colour yellow which represents electricity. reviewText:
Nihilumbra is, overall, a great experience. A platformer somewhere along the lines of Limbo, it's less atmoshperic, but its thought-provoking premisis, coupled with some intelligently designed platforming and puzzles, make it a real gem of the genre.
The game's short but thoughtful philosophical interludes are perfectly fitted within the environments that the game has you explore, and it succesfully conveys the feeling of a journey toward maturity, gradually finding out more about the world as it is and what you can (or can't) have an impact on. The narrator's remarks are frequent but never too revealing, thus leaving you the liberty to link and interprete the metaphors for yourself.
Nihilumbra also gradually opens up its gameplay through the aquisition of colours, with which you can change the environment. One lets you create ice, which helps you traverse certain sections more quickly, or enables you to make certain objects or enemies slide and fall, given that there is an initial momentum to begin with. Another is mud, which acts both as a means of slowing down - yourself and others -, stealthily traversing a section, as well as a sticky surface, allowing you to stick to walls or ceilings. Each of the six colours has its unique multiple purposes. The great thing about this is that most puzzles or obstacles you encounter along the way have multiple solutions, so you can do it your own way.
The aesthetics are very well designed - the diverse environments look beautiful, yet not majestic. The music used is very suitable as well, and nicely adapted to each of the worlds you explore. However, I think it's used in excess. Sure, since it's not trying to convey an atmosphere as tense and empty as Limbo's , I wouldn't have pleaded for complete silence, but there are some sections of the game which would have benefitted from less rather than more background noise.
While the main story mode is rather easy, and can be completed in around 3 hours, the real challenge here is represented by Void mode. It's a redesign of the original maps, but made much much much harder. So hard that I think the contrast between the main game, where I was never stuck for more than 2-3 minutes, and Void mode, where simply the first level of the first chapter took me around 20 minutes to complete, is a bit sharp.
Overall, I can only tell you to buy this game. It's fairly priced for the content it offers, it will delight you with its beautiful visuals and smart story analogies.

The combination of colors, textures, music and narration sets a very solemn, yet relaxing mood. The main part of the game is very short. It only took me about 4 hours to complete. However, once you complete it, you'll unlock “Void Mode” which is essentially hard mode. Void Mode offers the same levels but with different and much harder puzzles.

Conclusion:Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone that's a fan of platformers or puzzle-platformers. It's really unique and highly underrated. Nihilumbra is a very insightful, relaxing and fun experience. That's what this game is. It's more than just a game. It's an experience to be had.

reviewText:
Nihilumbra is a really hard game to review because it's almost impossible to describe properly.

You play as Born, a being that emerges from the Void & takes on a humanoid shape. You explore the world, gaining colours, each with an ability to help you progress. You 'paint' them onto a surface to activate that ability, whether it's making the surface slippery, sticky, burning hot, bouncy or conductive. You then use these colours to solve puzzles, defeat Void monsters & escape the Void as it hunts you across the side-scroller world.

Sounds a bit plain & simple, but it is actually a fabulous little game. The graphics are perfectly judged; pretty but simple, not overblown for a side-scroller. The music is as good as it gets, varied & often haunting & eerie.

The greatest part is the narration. It's not constant, but what there is, is a real asset to the game. I could never quite tell if it was Born's own voice berrating & encouraging him to resist & fight to exist, an external voice talking to Born, or simply a narrator talking to the player. The narration is presented in what can best be described as a moving picture-book, with the words that are being spoken appearing prominently on the screen in large text. You are able to play without stopping to wait for the text to fade though, which shows sensible design.

The puzzles are challenging, generally requiring you to make use of the newest colour, but always you have to think about all of them throughout. Even the length is perfectly balanced, with a 2nd play through built in if you haven't had enough, but doesn't necessarily add to the story.

In fact, I'm struggling to think of much that's wrong with Nihilumbra, aside from the fact that it is a very quirky game that won't appeal to everyone. At a stretch, it's not the ultimate in immersion, but given that Nihilumbra's main plot is only a few hours long, it doesn't need to be. Everything about it feels complete, a game that has fulfilled it's entire starting breif.

If you are interested in a well-rounded, well though-out & beautifully scripted game that is something totally different, then you will almost certainly get something out of Nihilumbra. I'm really pleased to be able to say I own & have played Nihilumbra.

Once you finish it (2-3 hours) you'll unlock the Void mode, and here is where the real game begins, with plenty of puzzles and challenges for you to complete. Sometimes is hard, but never overwhelming. And the difficulty is evenly spread through the levels, so all 5 worlds have roughly the same difficulty. If you beat it, there's a cool bonus that gives incentive to replay the Story mode. In the end, this is a nice cohesive game, with good gameplay.

There are a lot of nit picky things that you could say about this game. Like the fact that you can't use your mouse roller to choose diffrent colors so in the middle of trying to stop a red color from killing you, you must go to the corner and click the purple and in trying to do that the red color burns you to death. But then there are some really annoying things about it like the fact that if you die and there is a point where the narrator talk he will repeat it and if you die a lot he will repeat it AGAIN AND AGAIN.  Is the narrator suppost to be my conscious? He would always say stuff like You should feel bad" "You feel guilt" it was kinda like gauntlet where the wizard says PLAYER 2 IS HUNGRY. Except the wizard only said that when it was necessary not every 2 seconds.
It was like the narrator was trying to make me feel bad for this little black thing that had no personality or backstory.And he kept trying to remind you that HEY DONT FORGET TO FEEL AWFUL. Sometimes he would blatenly say something along the lines of you should just kill yourself because you were "ruining" the places you were leaving behind.
The puzzles are not challangeing and the monsters in the game make inovative and new ways to solve them impossible and they are so repetitive that you die 3000 times before you can get to the next checkpoint. It was cute at first but then it just got annoying and was no longer fun to play and had absolutly no replay value. It had a lot of potential and I was really excited to play it but in the end it was not worth the money."

reviewText:
I didn't really enjoy this as much as I thought I would, playing through the main quest. Once you finish it, the game opens up into a 'void' challenge which is significantly harder than the (easy) main storyline. I didn't enjoy it. It's not a 'revisit' or 'redo' of the original story line levels, but it focuses more on killing void creatures in thos enviroments, rather than exploring and puzzles.

Main storyline took me 2 hours, and i'm not a big fan of difficult platformers, so I had no interest in what may of been a longer definently more challenging mode. Honestly the controls themselves didn't lend themselves to faster paced more difficult platforming/killing, so even if i was grooving on the idea, i can assure you the controls would of kicked me out just as quickly as the narration.

I feel the narrator was relatively unessesary, and many of the lines of dialogue, i really felt were out of place, or didn't mesh well with the story. Honestly, it's game where the narration should really add to it, but more often than not i felt it pulling me out of the game because of lines i didn't expect or just lines that broke the feeling.

I normally go into this game expecting a big point, or big plot or big overarching theme 'redemption' 'exploration' 'overcoming of one's greif' 'growing up' honestly, I didn't feel any particular ONE theme from this game... and that saddens me because it could of been as enjoyable to me as Thomas was Alive if it had one thing and explored it well, rather than trying to touch on multiple things at once.

Unique mechanics, not particularly engaging though, and marred with questionable narration and thematic choices...

Get it really cheap for 2 hours of entertainment, more if you enjoy the more punishing execution style platformers, but be aware the mechanics themselves don't lend themselves well to the platform genres need of smooth, precise gameplay. It's a game that would of benefited more from a longer storyline or a more crisp singular point, than a second challenge mode and shorter story line. The story failed to buy me in, and so I was left, ultimately disappointed.

A second or less could make the difference in not getting through an obstacle.\n\nThere were times you needed to bounce so high that the figure you were controlling would go off the top of the screen. This made it very tough to stick" a landing or bounce just right. There was no way to avoid death repeatedly because you could not see the next screen of obstacles/enemies until you were in the line of fire or off the edge of a cliff.  I could not find any way to change the key mappings/bindings. So
date: I was stuck using WASD. That means my fingers were in the wrong position to quickly tap on numbers to change colors
recommended: I had to rely on the mouse wheel which means cycling through colors which takes more time than desired.  There were times I just left the game up in paused mode because I did not want to replay a prior part of a level (no save nearby). So the number of hours it took me to play is highly inflated with 8 hours while I slept or worked.\n\nFor me

reviewText:
Honestly, I expected much less from this game than I actually got. Till now, I didn't know a really good game from Spain, but this really changed my mind. The story is not that impressive, it's just a guy telling you something about life and comments the 'colors' you found, so that's not really a game to shed tears. On the other hand, the game requires you to use common sense, which means you only have to have a piece of brain to be able to pass through the whole game, the skill is not that required, it's more about repeating till you get it. The story line is more for people who want to get into calm mood, but reversed, void mode is for those, who really want to enjoy it and they do not mind repeating one part of game thousand times.

Pros:
Nice interface, the game is about void and the UI really looks like that.
Usage of common sense
The enviroment changes progressively, you do not insensibly pass through random maps.
Void difficulty is extremely funny
Platformer with unique mechanics
Cons:
It is way too short - I would like to play, but repeating maps is not that fun. If it had some kind of multiplayer, it would be great. Like you would have a chance to make your map, people would play it and that would be ranked by time, or you could be able to make a whole mod or something, but currently, it was pretty short.
Difficulty gap - The first difficulty was totally easy, but when I came to void difficulty, but I raged more than when I played Dark Souls, but as I stated above, you can pass through the game with zero skill, it is just repeating and common sense, but if there was some middle difficulty, it would at least make a game longer and people who are not that patient would at least be able to pass it.
8/10

reviewText:
Should probably caution on the fact that:

1) the game is very short (I beat it in 2 hours, this is without the challenge modes though).

2) the game is very easy (minus the challenge modes).

Now with those out of the way, let me say that Nihilumbra could be a hidden gem. It's just as good as some of the other indie greats like FEZ, Braid, or even Super Meat Boy (except, again, this game is way easier than those). The game makes use an intresting macanic where you paint surfaces with different colors that all have different effects - somewhat reminds me of Portal. If you want a game with logic puzzle like Portal (minus the humor though because this game gets somewhat depressing) and are okay with a short length like Portal then this game is for you.

Although I say the game is easy, the Challenge mode after beating the game really is hard, but I still feel like the game is only giving me the difficultys of Press A to win" Easy

reviewText:
Nihilumbra has you control a being who is questioning it's existence, in a sprawling, puzzle-filled world.

Unfortunately, I could not connect with this game.

The game has merits: the puzzles all work, there's no bugs (at least none that I encountered) and everything works as it should. The puzzles aren't challenging, but they are what they are, a little lite puzzle adventure.

Now, on to the reasons I wouldn't recommend the game. I could not get over the narrator. I'm sorry, maybe it was just me, but it bothered me so much. The line delivery wasn't great and the tone and tambre of the voice seemed purely to rely on being deep and kind-of sounding like a movie-trailer guy to bring any depth to the words spoken. For me, it really irked me.

Then, the story. I didn't like it. It was confusing, a little pretencious, and a little forced. The game felt as though the creator had came up with the idea for the puzzles and bent a story around it to package it.

Maybe you'll enjoy it, have a look over the trailer and see what you think, but for me, I sadly did not.

Nilesy

reviewText:
This game was just... uninteresting. The first few levels were pretty fun, getting used to the whole painting mechanic, but once I played with it for a while it got really boring. I tried hard to like this game, but the more I played, the more I didn't even want to finish it.

The story is cliche to say the least, and the narration absolutely ruined it (yes, I know you can turn it off, and I did). Instead of giving you bits and pieces for you to interpret, it shoves it down your throat. In fact, this game barely even has a story. It's kind of like they wanted to make a platformer that incorporated the whole painting technique and THEN they just kind of came up with some boring storyline just so you would feel like you had a reason to run through these levels.

The platforming is mediocre to say the least. The screen transitions in this game will absolutely mess you up. In a game where you need to know exactly what is around the corner to prevent your death, you don't get any warnings at all. Most of my deaths in this game were not due to the puzzles being challenging, but due to me not being able to see what I was walking into. You'll just be walking along, get to the end of the screen, the screen will transition and all of a sudden HOLY MOTHER OF GOD AN ENEM- dead.

I also found that sometimes I would breeze past a puzzle using a certain method, but if I tried to do that exact same thing in another spot, it wouldn't work. Like the one part where you needed to sneak past one of those flower monsters using the brown colour. Okay, worked fine. Then on the next level I try it again but NO, it didn't work, I had to use green to jump over it or something. I can't really remember, oh well.

When it comes to aesthetics the game is.. alright. There are some really nice looking parts in the game but I found that a lot of the background and level design just looked very dull. I think there was only one point in the game where I was walking through the forest across the fallen tree near the waterfalls that I actually said Wow
date: this is nice looking and unique and my eyes like it!" other than that the environments were forgettable.\n\nThe gameplay gets VERY repetitive. You find a flower. You get a new colour that has a different power. You learn how to use the power. You go through the level using the power in very self-explanitory ways. Run from the void. Repeat. The game really just tells you what to do half of the time

Summary: A good looking side-scrolling platform puzzler which offers little challenge and presents its story in a very overbearing fashion. Severe pacing problems left me bored and unwilling to complete it.

First impression: I won’t say review, because I will not be finishing the game. I made it to the third area (Ash desert) and it still feels like I’m in the tutorial. The game holds your hand despite not offering anything resembling a challenge. I assume that it becomes more interesting later in the game when you have more abilities that can interact. Moreover, I do not question the benefits of letting the player get used to the basics first and gradually increase the difficulty, but why let the game go on so long before doing so? While many games are able to present interesting challenges with a single mechanic, this one had not presented anything interesting even by my third ability.

The game looks good and the narrator is competent. Unfortunately the narration, which otherwise would be the game’s strong point, feels like it is trying to force me to feel something rather than letting me feel it. Rather than explaining what Born is feeling or thinking, it is saying that I am Born and “You are sad, you feel guilty, you will not escape.” In contrast to, for example, Thomas Was Alone, I felt completely disconnected to the story.

The combination of severe pacing problems and an overbearing narration makes me not recommend Nihilumbra. Sure, it is a cheap game and it looks good, but it is also boring.

Ok get this power, have it explained to you as opposed to figuring it out yourself, then go back through the same level, hear an explanation of what you just did (oh thanks), then go find another power and do it all over again.

The game has its qualities but it has as many jarring problems."

reviewText:
Simply put, I really did not like this game. Many of my complaints are mirrored by other reviewers. The narrator's voice is not very well acted, very repetitious, very trite, and just...constant. He shows up with zingers about finding your heart, how anger is dangerous, how it's important to feel sadness, and at times I found myself blinking in disbelief that the lines made it through to the final draft.

The gameplay is mediocre. It isn't outright bad, but it's just not very fun. You spend most of your time trying out different powers, which will give you the ability to: slide yourself and objects over ground, toast things (including you if you're not careful) with raging fires, make the ground 'bouncy' so everything springs off of it, create electricity to turn on circuits (and thus make puzzles 'run' their active elements), and a few others I'm probably forgetting. That's the thing - the abilities are really just forgettable. Platforming staples like 'bouncy bouncy' need a little twist to make them interesting. Otherwise you are just back to Mario and spring-boards again.

Personally, I found the story tedious and unoriginal. You play as a sliver of the void, inexplicably cast onto the earth, and running from the 'void' - an understandably featureless foe who chases you across the map on occasion, and summons minions to try and slay you in a few different ways. The rule in this game is Insta-Death, which would be fun and exciting if the monsters were not so often acting in entirely novel ways, reacting unpredictably to tiny mistakes on your behalf (e.g. missing a small spot on the floor with the 'paint-on' effects), or just being RIGHT THERE as you enter a new frame. They also tend to have (IMO) awkward hit-boxes, such that you think you are okay springing over them, only to mysteriously die when you get too close.

I finished the main game in a little over two hours. It's a decently priced game, and I don't have much to complain about here. There is a 'void' mode unlocked after beating the main game, but I found the game suddenly veered from stupidly easy, to stupidly hard when I reached this mode - I never found the game reached that 'sweet spot' for me, between the two poles. I found myself, ridiculously, stuck on the very first 'room' of Void mode, perfectly able to solve the 'puzzle' (jumping over a charging enemy by building a little altitude), and occasionally succeeding (only to die on the next room) but almost entirely unable to execute it.

Trading Cards are a nice perk, and I sold them for an effective $1 reduction in price.

Achievements are what you would expect. About half are for clearing levels and winning the game, or objectives you can't avoid completing. The other are fairly obscure, and I believe there is a handful of hidden ones. Nothing too staggering here, but par for the course.

Overall, I disliked this game, and would probably rate it something like 4/10. It wasn't pull-out-your-hair bad, but on reflection, I think it was not worth the money. A couple hours wasted, no harm done, but nothing I can give a 'thumb up' to with a good conscience.

reviewText:
The game consists of 5 stages that take about 15-20 minutes each to complete. So you'll probably finish the game in about 2 hours or less.

In each stage you get a new color that you click and drag across the ground to make it slippery, bouncy, sticky, burn things, or connect electricity. Honestly I was expecting the game to have controller support with such basic controls. It has none; keyboard only.

The narration is alright. The gameplay is honestly very boring throughout the first two levels. I was about to give up on the game; I felt no reason to continue playing. I wasn't having fun and it was boring. After forcing myself to keep going it got a little more interesting in the 3rd-5th levels.

Overall a fairly average and short game. The file size is fairly big, about 2.3 gb. I usually expect small 2d games like this to be around 500 MB or less. It doesn't really seem to have any replayability and I have no desire to play it again so I just uninstalled it after I beat it. I got it in a humble bundle for $1 with two other games. I've seen it on sale for $1 by itself before too; so pick it up while it's cheap if you want to. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone I know unless they really wanted it or got it very cheap.

reviewText:
Discover the beautiful world of Nihilumbra and join Born on his adventure to find himself whilst trying to escape from his inevitable curse.
Born was created from the absolute nothingness: The Void. But somehow he separates himself from the black emptiness and appears in the world. This is where his long odyssey begins, in which he will learn how to use the colors around him to gain powerful abilities and transform the world.

However, his experiences come at a high price. The Void must be one. It seeks to reclaim him and will never stop chasing him, destroying everything in its path along the way.
To survive, Born will have to condemn the earth he walks to its inevitable obliteration by The Void...

reviewText:
It looked interesting, but I was somewhat disappointed.

Art is ok, not exactly fantastic but fitting enough, I've seen far worse. There were some alright relaxing music tunes.

Level design didn't feel too great, not impressive or challenging (in story mode; you unlock another mode when finishing the game where you progress through whole new levels and which I played shortly; that mode is apparently harder, but I had no motivation to try that too much). Logic lacks a bit too. Why would you be in a forest and find mechanical devices to block or help you on your way? I didn't remember any explanation for that. I guess gameplay-wise there could have been ways for the developers to make things work the same just with different, more logical and ambiance-fitting objects.

There is a constant neutral narration throughout the levels. The voice quickly became tedious to listen to, and I soon didn't care about what he was telling as it felt pretentious and repetitive. The game dearly tries to make you feel like you were on a meaningful journey of life and death, but it didn't strike me. There are some lines so dripping with a tryhard-meaningfulness that I couldn't resist to roll my eyes a bit. Or maybe I'm just hardboiled? I don't know.

Regarding the gameplay: You find flowers resembling colors. These colors give you certain powers to draw on surfaces. One color makes you move faster when walking the ground it's on, another makes you (or enemies slower), another makes you jump higher and so on. It's moderately interesting, but not fleshed out too much in the story mode, which is why someone has to get through that first to see the other, already-mentioned second mode in which he can use all these colors to a bigger extend.

I didn't exactly like the progression of the game: There are clear lines between the levels and settings. I think it was first an icy area, then a moderate forest, a hot desert, after that some volcano area and one more special place. In each you find one flower/color. I prefer a less narrowly drawn progression in games, as this is a very classic" or predictable/"boring" scheme (pick your side) to make someone advance through."

reviewText: Played it on my mobile device and liked it, playing it again on steam with hd-graphics and better sound quality, I was literaly blown away. Nihilumbra is a 2D platformer with an extremely compelling art style and story.

Story: Without spoiling too much in Nihilumbra you play as Born a being from the void and you set out to find your purpose while the void tries to stop you. In short this game has a great story and I encourage that you see for yourself.

Gameplay: Nihilumbra is a 2D platformer were you must use colors to your advantage. Each color has a unique property that you can use to your advantage whether it's going through terrain, avoiding enemies or solving puzzles. In this game there is no way to kill enemies yourself until later in the game you also need to use your enviroment to help you. Using colors in my opinion was a great way to expand the depth in the gameplay and make it much less simple but not too complicated.

Presentation: The art style of this game is beautiful. It really shows difference between the different levels you advance through and uses a wide range of colors. Not to mention that in this version there is now an art gallery where you can look at concept art, sketchs and level designs.

reviewText: I absolutely loved this game. Short, but very powerful. Somehow, this game held a lot of meaning with me. I highly suggest that you play Nihilumbra.\n\n

The story is a terrifying, dark, twisted, tragic and sad journey, but delivered in the most subtle and gentle tone imagineable. I suspect some sense of spirituality or religious material as some of the inspiration or perhaps the basis of some elements. Yet, I percieve this more as a metaphysical mirror of the nature of life, death and reality, presented in a way that wouldn't frighten children;  even if the subject matter is a little too deep for them. The somber soundtrack suits the mood of the story very well.

I don't think this game misrepresented anything in the description, however, I was a little disappointed. I don't think it's a bad game at all, just not really for me. Also, really short and extremely concise in every aspect.

I am recommending this review based on the fact that had I really looked at the game descriptions, I might not have gotten it, but there were really alot of positive reviews, probably by alot of people who like very casual games.

Nihilumbra has great art, a soothing soundtrack, wonderfully original puzzle mechanics, and a story that you want to see through to the end.  The different abilities are given to you gradually and appropriately ramp up the complexity of the puzzles at a good pace.  The game is split between two parts: The first time through and all of the the levels re-done as a bonus hard mode (called void mode) once you complete the game.  The first time through the puzzles aren't all that challenging but serve as warm up as you get used to all of the different puzzle mechanics.  The puzzles are never boring, but walk a fine line between being solvable fairly quickly but also satisfying to do so.  After you get to the end, the void mode opens up and really makes you think and be on your toes.  The puzzles are never frustrating but can be quite challenging.  The story is written such that the void mode makes sense narratively and motivates you to want to finish it to get the 2nd (final) ending.  The void mode levels aren't narrated as the main playthrough is which is a bummer, but just a minor complaint.  Very much worth the complete playthrough!

Nihilumbra, by Beautifun Games, is one of those games; when stumbled upon and given time, you really get to see all the heart it holds, and the care it had been given. When you are introduced to its world, you can't help but marvel at its art, deep in the frigid mountains to the ruins of a city long abandoned, and you're drawn further in by the awesome music that it emits. It truly tells an interesting tale.

You are Born. A being that escaped from the Void to see and live a life for yourself. As you traverse Nihilumbra's world, you come across various 'colors', which act as both your tools and your weapons. For instance, Blue is Ice, allowing your character to either move quicker and jump further or to allow your enemies to slip and slide off a ledge to be trapped or to their untimely doom. Each color that you get are often used in conjunction with one another to help solve the game's many puzzles. Puzzles that I found very appealing, and interesting, some of them simple, some of them more complex. It's all about how you analyze the situation and how you yourself are going to utilize what has been given. With a solid control scheme and responsiveness, the game didn't feel it was trying to work against the player, which is crucial for a puzzle platformer.

When you start, it gives you a 'Story-esque' tutorial, here is where you learn how to play, what to expect, and how Born and everything around you reacts to your actions. It was interesting actually, and didn't feel as if the game was holding my hand, but rather an introduction. It was a nice touch by developers. After the 'story' as been completed, you are far from being finished. Now, you must right the wrongs that you have done, and this is where the real fun begins. It was a lot of fun figuring out the puzzles, and after completing each one, the accomplishment was indeed satisfying.

Overall, it's a game that is well worth its price. With an overall great infrastructure, and charm, Nihilumbra has easily become one of my favorites. I highly recommend it to those who enjoys puzzle platformers, or to any gamer in general. It's that easy to pick up and play, and easily be drawn into its fantastical world.

The game is a platformer with some clever mechanics, divided into two modes. The initial story mode is effectively an extended tutorial with little actual challenge. New mechanics are introduced very slowly, while the plot presented at this point is about what you'd expect from a casual indie game; very forgettable and completely predictable. The atmosphere is pretty nice though, and the voice is pleasant to listen to.

Once you finish the story you get access to the extended challenge mode; think Super Meat Boy dark world. The mechanics are much the same, but the game tries to add extra challenge by presenting a lot more complex scenarios. Unfortunately for the most part these extended challenges end up being nothing more than timing puzzles or trial and error memorization of where the enemies spawn.

Get this full price if you really like precise timing puzzles. Wait for a sale if you like platformers and artsy games. Skip it if you're looking for deep or thought evoking challenges.

reviewText:
Nihilumbra, by Beautifun Games, is one of those games; when stumbled upon and given time, you really get to see all the heart it holds, and the care it had been given. When you are introduced to its world, you can't help but marvel at its art, deep in the frigid mountains to the ruins of a city long abandoned, and you're drawn further in by the awesome music that it emits. It truly tells an interesting tale.

You are Born. A being that escaped from the Void to see and live a life for yourself. As you traverse Nihilumbra's world, you come across various 'colors', which act as both your tools and your weapons. For instance, Blue is Ice, allowing your character to either move quicker and jump further or to allow your enemies to slip and slide off a ledge to be trapped or to their untimely doom. Each color that you get are often used in conjunction with one another to help solve the game's many puzzles. Puzzles that I found very appealing, and interesting, some of them simple, some of them more complex. It's all about how you analyze the situation and how you yourself are going to utilize what has been given. With a solid control scheme and responsiveness, the game didn't feel it was trying to work against the player, which is crucial for a puzzle platformer.

When you start, it gives you a 'Story-esque' tutorial, here is where you learn how to play, what to expect, and how Born and everything around you reacts to your actions. It was interesting actually, and didn't feel as if the game was holding my hand, but rather an introduction. It was a nice touch by developers. After the 'story' as been completed, you are far from being finished. Now, you must right the wrongs that you have done, and this is where the real fun begins. It was a lot of fun figuring out the puzzles, and after completing each one, the accomplishment was indeed satisfying.

Overall, it's a game that is well worth its price. With an overall great infrastructure, and charm, Nihilumbra has easily become one of my favorites. I highly recommend it to those who enjoys puzzle platformers, or to any gamer in general. It's that easy to pick up and play, and easily be drawn into its fantastical world.

A relatively short game from Spain, Nihilumbra. You are Born. Spewed forth from the Void itself. Without meaning, without light, without hope. You have nothing and are nothing. You travel from one out of five different areas in search of self and life. Soon discovering you aren't the only thing wrought from the Void you hasten your venture even further into the world, bringing to light - colors. Each color has it's own power and individuality to them. Each one is new and fills your character with a sense of wonder. With colors come actions, with actions come consequences.

A proverbial story about the world around you and the importance of self-identification.

You are Born.

Pros:
Art Style - Almost bland at times, which works well with the story, the further you go in, the lighter and more vivid things become.

Voice Acting - For one voice actor, he did an amazing job. From swelled with sorrow to brimming with hope. You can hear it well in his dialogue.

Controls - Using a combination of your keyboard for movement and you mouse for the colors makes for a versatile yet easy to manage control and feel for the game itself.

Gameplay - Almost reminiscent of Ori, which I had played before this. It relies heavily on using your new found skills to conform to the world around you without abandoning your previous colors. Mixing two, sometimes more makes for a very unique game play style.

Menu - Easy to navigate menu, settings, options. The menu itself is almost engulfed in darkness which helps to set the mood even more.

Music - If a game's music keeps up with the pace of what's going on screen, I think the composer or artist has done there job right. This one manages it almost perfectly with some repetition throughout.

Replay Value - After completing the game, you will unlock Void mode, an even more difficult adventure which will punish you even more than the casual campaign. After beating that you'll unlock the special language. The language of kings, bro. Good addition to an otherwise short game.

Difficulty - With a well paced difficult curve, you shouldn't find yourself dying too much, the easier you grasp your new color, the quicker your feet will carry you.


Cons:
Advancing Too Fast - If you journey too fast the dialogue will get cut off. It's better to stop and wait until the dialogue is finished before moving on which felt a bit too tedious.

Screen Transitioning - Sometimes you'll find yourself dying from moving onto the next screen and not knowing what is there or having a projectile thrown in your face. Blindsides you a tad, didn't care much for that.

Repetitive - While the first two levels are nice you will quickly come to terms with the fact that you'll be doing the other levels in a similar fashion. Enter. Color. Void. This could go either way for you. For me it was a con.


Conclusion:
I recommend this game if you like indie hidden gems, platforming and a story rich, sometimes puzzling game.

Which ever option you go with, in the end, you'll be Born.

The game is a platformer with some clever mechanics, divided into two modes. The initial story mode is effectively an extended tutorial with little actual challenge. New mechanics are introduced very slowly, while the plot presented at this point is about what you'd expect from a casual indie game; very forgettable and completely predictable. The atmosphere is pretty nice though, and the voice is pleasant to listen to.

Once you finish the story you get access to the extended challenge mode; think Super Meat Boy dark world. The mechanics are much the same, but the game tries to add extra challenge by presenting a lot more complex scenarios. Unfortunately for the most part these extended challenges end up being nothing more than timing puzzles or trial and error memorization of where the enemies spawn.

Get this full price if you really like precise timing puzzles. Wait for a sale if you like platformers and artsy games. Skip it if you're looking for deep or thought evoking challenges.

Nihilumbra is a cute action platformer. It is definitely a puzzle game, and requires either a creative mind or an online guide for some of the harder levels.

It is twice as long as it first appears, and you very much have to earn your happy ending. Nevertheless, it has a very well-told, if minimal, story. And it doesn't suffer for being minimal - the simplicity is actually part of what makes the story work.

Its gameplay is simple to learn but it may take some time before you'll discover everything you can do with your powers. As a fairly uncreative person, I discovered some abilities entirely by accident and others only with the help of walkthroughs.

The only reasonable complaint I can imagine is that it is clearly a port of a smartphone game - nevertheless, the port is VERY well done and I find that the controls work better on my computer than on my smartphone. It feels like the PC version was ported to smartphones, not vice-versa.

After playing, I would be willing to pay twice the normal price for this game. If it's on sale, there is no reason to not buy it, and I think it's a steal even for the full $8.

Overall 10/10

Nihilumbra, by Beautifun Games, is one of those games; when stumbled upon and given time, you really get to see all the heart it holds, and the care it had been given. When you are introduced to its world, you can't help but marvel at its art, deep in the frigid mountains to the ruins of a city long abandoned, and you're drawn further in by the awesome music that it emits. It truly tells an interesting tale.

You are Born. A being that escaped from the Void to see and live a life for yourself. As you traverse Nihilumbra's world, you come across various 'colors', which act as both your tools and your weapons. For instance, Blue is Ice, allowing your character to either move quicker and jump further or to allow your enemies to slip and slide off a ledge to be trapped or to their untimely doom. Each color that you get are often used in conjunction with one another to help solve the game's many puzzles. Puzzles that I found very appealing, and interesting, some of them simple, some of them more complex. It's all about how you analyze the situation and how you yourself are going to utilize what has been given. With a solid control scheme and responsiveness, the game didn't feel it was trying to work against the player, which is crucial for a puzzle platformer.

When you start, it gives you a 'Story-esque' tutorial, here is where you learn how to play, what to expect, and how Born and everything around you reacts to your actions. It was interesting actually, and didn't feel as if the game was holding my hand, but rather an introduction. It was a nice touch by developers. After the 'story' as been completed, you are far from being finished. Now, you must right the wrongs that you have done, and this is where the real fun begins. It was a lot of fun figuring out the puzzles, and after completing each one, the accomplishment was indeed satisfying.

Overall, it's a game that is well worth its price. With an overall great infrastructure, and charm, Nihilumbra has easily become one of my favorites. I highly recommend it to those who enjoys puzzle platformers, or to any gamer in general. It's that easy to pick up and play, and easily be drawn into its fantastical world.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Nihilumbra. A Bit Pretentious and A Bit Overrated.Genre: 2D Platformer with Story.
Developed & Published by: BeautiFun Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Preamble
This is an overrated game. As I sit here and think about my experience with this game, that is all I can think. It got a lot of fanfare when it came out in 2013 but I can’t figure out why it did. This isn't really anything new for the genre and mostly just toes the line of what's come before. Maybe that's just me.

Story Thoughts
Nihilumbra is a 2D puzzle platformer where you follow Born, a being that fled something called “the Void”. You journey through multiple “areas” with various puzzles to be solved. All while being narrated/told what you’re feeling the entire time. The game gives off a feeling of being pretentious, whether that was intended or not. I didn't find the story to be all that new, interesting or even good. It simply existed to talk to me about life, death and acceptance of said life. However, I feel like other games have handled it in a better, less ham-fisted way. As it is, Nihilumbra is all about that point and well, leaves a lot to be desired because of it.

Platforming
The platforming and puzzle solving itself isn’t too bad. It’s just really forgiving with the difficulty increasing slowly and steadily the entire campaign but never getting too challenging. The only challenge the game really creates is switching between the different colors/powers quickly. Outside of that, there was only one puzzle I got stuck on and that was because I didn’t realize I could use the brown color to stick to the floor while a magnet was running nearby. One puzzle out of the entire experience. Not a really good sign.

PC Settings
Settings are really basic but unsurprisingly so. It has v-sync, some resolution options and that’s about it. But as its a 2D game, it doesn't really need much. So, not a big deal. Graphics are reasonably ok, though I don’t think they’re the best we’ve ever seen in this genre. Not even back in 2013. Sound is passable but there isn’t much depth to it. The soundtrack itself is overwhelming repetitive and you will quickly tire of each area’s new theme. A mute option would have been loved.

Final Thoughts
I’m not sure how I missed playing this platformer when it came out nearly two years ago, during a time I was all into platformers. Playing it now, well, leaves a feeling of ”mehness” to it. Sorry, I can’t think of another word to describe this feeling and that word is certainly not useful. However, as the game works and there’s nothing inherently wrong with it (other than being overrated/pretentious), I can think of worse ways you could waste two hours of your time. But I can also think of better uses.

Nihilumbra is a nice little way to spend the afternoon. It's nothing truly incredible, the visuals don't really have a unified style, the environments are a bit samey and the narration seems forced, but in the end, I enjoyed it.\n\nNihilumbra has a fairly unique set of mechanics that make for decent puzzles, the character sprite looks incredible, and there's something very original about the story, becoming more introspective and character-focused than I ever imagined it would be. If I'm honest, I expected this to be sort of a lazy indie game clone: Bastion had narration, Limbo had bleak environments and silouhettes, Tag had paint that covers surfaces and alters their attributes, but there's still something unique and special about Nihilumbra, and that's the story. Even though the story centers around (generously speaking) only one character, and even despite the cliched appearance, I was left satisfied nonetheless.

Nihilumbra is a cute action platformer. It is definitely a puzzle game, and requires either a creative mind or an online guide for some of the harder levels.

It is twice as long as it first appears, and you very much have to earn your happy ending. Nevertheless, it has a very well-told, if minimal, story. And it doesn't suffer for being minimal - the simplicity is actually part of what makes the story work.

Its gameplay is simple to learn but it may take some time before you'll discover everything you can do with your powers. As a fairly uncreative person, I discovered some abilities entirely by accident and others only with the help of walkthroughs.

The only reasonable complaint I can imagine is that it is clearly a port of a smartphone game - nevertheless, the port is VERY well done and I find that the controls work better on my computer than on my smartphone. It feels like the PC version was ported to smartphones, not vice-versa.

After playing, I would be willing to pay twice the normal price for this game. If it's on sale, there is no reason to not buy it, and I think it's a steal even for the full $8.
