Nihilumbra first appears as yet another 2D puzzle platformer in a long line of indie games trying to follow the successes of Braid and Limbo from years back.  Once the game begins, it’s quite clear those assumptions are not without reason, but diving deeper reveals a much bolder game with grander ambitions than the typical modern sidescroller.

Video Review - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jD7gFizUTw&list=PL3DFDLFub9-pGLzqUqejMmyNwvJo5Qz7C&index=1

The player controls a creature named “Born” as it escapes an empty void into the physical world. As Born progresses, a narrator will explain the futility of the whole affair. The narrator insists the void will relentlessly chase Born down as the “the void must be one.” The narrator argues the world is harsh and doesn’t care what the fate of Born will be. The narrator repeats Born is not a part of the physical world and cannot live there. Born is nothing. It’s all pointless. Born will die. Nihilumbra, as its name suggests, is a game about Nihilism – a philosophy asserting the meaninglessness of life.
The message is presented in a brutally heavy handed way. It has the subtlety of a hammer slamming on a nail. Perhaps some will find this off-putting, but the decision to forgo nuance results in a gut wrenching emotional conflict between Born and the narrator. As Born moves through the world in spite of the harsh rhetoric, the narrator can be seen as Born’s internal doubt. Progressing through the world feels like an accomplishment, not only for overcoming obstacles, but for overcoming the narrator’s negativity. Eventually, the narrator will admit Born is putting up a good fight. One of the best scenes is early on, when a set of obstacles tests Born’s physical abilities. Born is not strong enough, nor quick enough, but maybe - maybe Born is smart enough.
The Nihilistic philosophy of the narrator is constantly undermined throughout the adventure.  The narrator will present a point in their favor, and quickly offer a counterpoint, countering that point, and then countering it again. The narrator argues with itself, and can be seen as a debate inside Born’s head. While the always in pursuit void is a threat, doubt and anxiety within Born are the central conflicts.
The narrator, while maintaining the end is nigh, provides tons of encouragement to push Born and the player onwards. It offers assurances just as much as it offers doubt.  It’s never an unlikable presence and more often than not feels like a good friend and ally. As Born comes across and absorbs elemental powers, the narrator will instruct on how to use them. The elements themselves are typical of this type of game. There is slippery ice, bouncy grass, and destructive lava. Sand and Electricity are the stand outs. With Electricity, the player can create currents sending power to contraptions like elevators and turrets. Sand is the most versatile of them all, allowing the player to slow enemies, withstand fierce winds, stick to walls, and silence footsteps. The narrator will also take the time to explain various enemies around the world. Some chase, some shoot, some will erase elemental powers, and other just suck … quite literally.
The game is masterfully paced, presenting these abilities one at a time, but not spending very much time with a single element on its own. The game follows a formula where it teaches an element in a safe tutorial, then asks the player to use the element by itself, and finally tasks the player with using the element in conjunction with previously learned abilities. There is always a feeling of progress and of learning something new with every scenario. Again, there is nothing completely unique about the gameplay, but it is well executed.
The only blemishes to the game are tedious chase sequences in which the Void has found Born and attempts to reabsorb them. These moments are used as an equivalent of boss battles, happening at the end of an act and requiring mastery of that acts new mechanics. Nihilumbra’s puzzles are clever, but are never a challenge. As such, the problem with these battles is twofold. Often the puzzles are too easy to solve, leaving Born to wait on the camera to move forward. Alternatively, the full breadth of a puzzle isn’t unveiled quick enough and can’t be completed in a timely fashion resulting in a frustrating death. These sequences are only a small portion of the game, but are definitely its weakest points.
The games real strengths rarely come from the gameplay by itself, but rather how the powers, enemies, and puzzles blend beautifully with the story being told. As Born gains new abilities, it becomes clear they are becoming more attached to the world around them than they are to the void giving chase. The narrator notes, Born was nothing when it left the void, but through these learned abilities has definitely become something. With this revelation, the game shifts from being a dramatic depression factory into a somewhat uplifting criticism of Nihilism.
What Nihilumbra does is nothing extraordinary, but it wraps itself in a protective blanket of rich atmosphere and tastefully direct writing perfect for the moody teenager in all of us. Its story and gameplay meld seamlessly with excellent music and art to create a completely cohesive vison throughout its entirety. Nihilumbra knows what it is, isn’t ashamed of it, and preforms with a high grade of quality.

Nihlumbra is true to its name: a game about Nihilism and a little umbral shadow that escapes from the nothingness and wants to LIVE! It’s all about trying to escape your fate, and seems like it’ll end with the typical Nihilist “everything is meaningless and hopeless” but you’ll be pleasantly surprised. You control a little shadow who learns about colors, each of which has a different effect: Blueish-white = ice, Green = trampoline, red = fire, brown = sticky, yellow = electricity. You combine these skills as you go along to solve puzzles and try to escape your fate.

Let me preface my review by saying that a lot of the negative reviews are unfair. One of the main criticisms of this game is that the main story is easy, and the so-called afterparty known as “Void Mode” is insanely hard. That’s because they’re thinking of it as one continous game, when it’s not. It’s essentially a “Story mode” where you learn the skills, do some levels of varying difficulty (usually easy to medium), you enjoy an interesting story in an interesting world as you go along. It ends with the words “The End.” You can play to this point and have a wonderful experience, perhaps not one that’s 100% worth the $7.99 asking price, but almost certainly worth $5 and DEFINITELY worth the $1.99 I paid for it on sale. If you’re a hardcore puzzler, then you get BONUS levels with some added difficulty. Yes, the bonus levels are GRUELING, with some colors (i.e. powers) forbidden in certain areas, few (if any) save points, and really tricky timing at times. (Like starting off a level with something directly behind you and chasing you.) To be honest, I played a few levels of the Void Mode and felt a little cheated, because I looked at a level and said “Oh, I know what to do! The story mode taught me this! Oh, wait…I can’t use fire here. Or ice. I have no effin’ clue how to get past these 6 enemies without dying over and over.” A lot of them weren’t about planning or skill, mostly about finding the ONE solution that was correct, whereas the main game allowed some creative thinking and was forgiving with your various options. Each “world” of levels ends with a “You’re being chased by the Void, so solve these puzzles really quickly” which is frustrating at times, but it’s kind of like the Boss battle of each world, so it works, and it’s a nice change of pace I guess.

Pros:
+Great music!
+Great art – complex yet minimalist
+Interesting game mechanic with tons of cool powers to mix and match
+Atmospheric – Each area of the world reflects the color you’ve just learned. E.g. You learn red in a volcano level with steam and lava. You learn the blue/white color in an ice world with howling wild and falling snow.

Neutral:
~ Voice acting is AWFUL, but I put it in neutral because there’s an option to turn it off. It seems unnecessary anyway, because all the words are on the screen, and the voice ruins the atmosphere by interjecting itself all the time. I turned it off after a few levels.
~ I’m not a fan of the end-of-the-set-of-levels chase scene, but some people might appreciate the change of pace, so I’ll put this here.

Cons:
- As mentioned above, your experience will either be A) very short if you only play through the story, but will be casual and enjoyable or B) long and grueling, if you play Void Mode. So it’s either a length problem or a difficulty problem, but not actually both. Paradox.

Overall: 8.5/10
Story Mode: 9/10. Fun, casual, but not overly challenging.
Void mode: 4/10. Punishing. Not for the faint of heart. Skippable.

Tl;dr version: Buy it, if only for the story mode.

reviewText: Gameplay-wise, this game is a fairly mediocre puzzle-platformer, but it has absolutely beautiful art and a fun little nihilistic storyline. It's short (except for the very difficult Void Mode, which I gave up on very quickly), cheap, and worth playing through.

Nihilumbra is alright. It's cheap enough to be easy to recommend. New game plus is
frustrating at times, but it's optional. overall, it's a fun game for killing a few hours with
very little invesntment. More information is down below

The game has issues, primarily due to it being a mobile port:

- The keys cannot be rebound, and you cannont assign custom keys to particular abilities.
- There are few options, and what options are present are icons instead of text. I had no
idea what they did.
- The controls are tempermental at times. If you use an ability too quickly, the ability will
be ineffective.
- some abilites don't look right in some situations  brown can make you stick to
nothing or inside walls if you stick at certain points . It doesn't effect gamplay
but it does look goofy.
- The new game plus mode can be frustrating. You can easily make small mistakes that
forces a reset. In particular, pushing boxes into walls will make them unmovable. if you
have no way to destroy the box, you are forced to restart. In addition, some enemy
placements feel unfair The first level in the void run is a good example. There
is an enemy immediately on screen, and you have to react fast to avoid a death.
Because you can't bind colors to keys, you have no way to quickly select a color. Most
early deaths will be because you didn't know what color is needed for the next screen.

The game does have a lot going for it:

- It's cheap at all times.
- It can be finished quickly. (2 hours)
- There is a new game plus mode that adds to the run time and gives more of a challange.
- The game allows for a lot of freedom with the mechanics.
- Everything looks and sounds great.
- It is fun and satisfying to beat the levels quickly.

This was a beautiful game. The main game was really easy, so it's good for beginners like me (I suck at this kind of games...).\n\nThe story, however, is either a hit or miss, depending on who plays it. I found it interesting and anyone with depression or other mental disorder should at least try it - I didn't know I needed to hear what Nihilumbra had to say before my friend recommended it to me, and I'm happy I played it.

Nihilumbra is a nice little way to spend the afternoon. It's nothing truly incredible, the visuals don't really have a unified style, the environments are a bit samey and the narration seems forced, but in the end, I enjoyed it.\n\nNihilumbra has a fairly unique set of mechanics that make for decent puzzles, the character sprite looks incredible, and there's something very original about the story, becoming more introspective and character-focused than I ever imagined it would be. If I'm honest, I expected this to be sort of a lazy indie game clone: Bastion had narration, Limbo had bleak environments and silouhettes, Tag had paint that covers surfaces and alters their attributes, but there's still something unique and special about Nihilumbra, and that's the story. Even though the story centers around (generously speaking) only one character, and even despite the cliched appearance, I was left satisfied nonetheless.

NIhilumbra combines the best features of the independent production : climate ( brilliant narrative and graphic design ) and ideas ( use a variety of mechanisms based on the laws of physics ) . Well worth it!
It's not a professionally polished game (e.g. it's bad dubbed). But it's a fun game nevetheless.
Story could have had more weight in it,but still a satisfactory playing experience. Would only recommend buying during a sale.\n
